title: Why are Tesla cars so expensive even though they have fewer parts than a normal car? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Tesla Model 3 is not terribly expensive compared to a full battery car (BEV) of similar range, such as a Chevy Bolt, perhaps $5–10K more. All are expensive because Li batteries are expensive and many are needed to give acceptable range (200+ miles). They also need a complicated liquid cooling system to protect the batteries and electronic management of their charging and output. The disappointment is that the Model 3 was never available for $35K w/ full $7.5K federal tax credit (plus state credits), as most of the ~400k people who left a $1k reservation expected. Many buyers feel the extra price of a Model 3 is worth it, considering Tesla’s better charging network, more extensive touch screen, and faster acceleration. They were also known for convenient service with mobile rangers, though once Model 3’s were out in volume, many owners have become frustrated with service. The Model S & X are more custom-made, with aluminum frames, and have some expensive parts found in luxury vehicles such as air suspension. Tesla claims the total cost of ownership is competitive with a similar gas car, even stating their prices “with fuel savings” on their website. Fueling (charging) at home will cost ~50% of gasoline (hybrid like Prius), but using Tesla superchargers will cost ~2x gasoline, both depending upon where you live. Also, if you don’t drive often, the batteries and electronics will decay away charge as it sits (~6 mi range per day). If parked in a cold garage or outdoors, it will use even more to keep the battery warm so keep it plugged in. Indeed, in 32 F weather, it will use all the output of a 120 VAC home circuit just to keep the batteries warm (won’t even add charge).

DISCLAIMER: I don't own a Tesla - I have three friends who do. I've ridden in them many times and they have no complaints so far. This is the reason I will be getting one someday. Tesla cars are expensive for three reasons: Tesla cars require batteries. As previous answers have covered well, these are expensive.Tesla uses different techniques for producing cars, compared to legacy car makers. Building gigafactories with robot and conveyor belt production lines is an expensive endeavor.Tesla cars rely on great programming to run well. Yes, build quality is one thing (and technicians who work on other car makes rave over the build quality of Teslas - sorry Tesla haters!) but quality programming is where Teslas stand out. Paying top programmers is not cheap, and updates are needed very often to fix bugs and counter ever increasing cyber threats.A previous answer to this question stated that "Tesla is becoming obsolete". Now I've stopped laughing, I'd like to address this rather hilarious claim. What most people don't seem to realise is that Tesla is a very young car company, and is having to make it's way through the minefield of the 21st century. Legacy car makers did not have this issue! They didn't have to deal with the internet, and therefore were not subject to howls of abuse by people who don't even own the car in question (looking at you, Jared Fox)Reviews back then were made by the companies, and were, of course, glowing with positive praise with hardly an utterance for how inefficient, unsafe and ugly they wereAnyone who says Tesla is obsolete, going bankrupt, makes shitty products, is run by a moron, etc, is ignoring these facts: Jeep cars had an issue with bursting into flames due to a poorly placed gas tank - did I mention that this issue goes back to 1970 with the Ford Pinto? You would think they would have learned?Fires in ICE cars are far more common than the media would have you know. Tesla fires are much more interesting (and profitable!) because they act like clickbait. The hate is real.VW was run by a corrupt CEO who promptly resigned when Dieselgate erupted. What leadership!GM was bailed out by the Federal government before becoming the vastly successful business it is todayAny CEO you care to mention is weird in some way. But they are all geniuses in some way, and deserve our respect.Tesla cars have the best safety ratings in the car industryTesla cars have the best range in the EV industryTesla has one of the best service setups in the car industryTesla is setting the standard in the industry for what an electric car should beAnd finally, no company is perfect. Every company ever created so far was created by humans and is run by humans. Expecting Tesla, or any other car maker, to be perfect is frankly ludicrous (pun intended).

They have fewer parts and almost 1/2 of them are not made by Tesla. The company has a single plant and has been incapable - with some exceptions - to meet monthly quotas. So, since supply is low and the demographic which purchases Teslas average 250% of the median American income, tends to be older, do not have children in the home they can afford to overpay and Tesla has no surplus of vehicles simply because it can’t produce enough vehicles - or replacement parts. So sufficient demand for low supply and enough people with disposable income to buy the hype to buy the car. Charging station today at Bear Mtn. State Park in upstate NY near middle class and upper class visitors. 4 charging stations. We watched to see if there was a single Tesla being charged or in the parking lot of about 500 cars. Not one. We saw 6 cars getting charged over a period of 5 hours, 2 Chevy Bolts, 2 Hyundais and a Jaguar i pace and one Nissan Leaf. No Teslas. All except the Jaugar are far cheaper to buy, insure and service than any Tesla.

What makes you think they have less parts? Do they have power locks? Windows? Adjustible seats? Stereo/Infotainment? Brakes? Shocks? Steering components? Body Panels? Mirrors? etc, etc. The only thing missing is about 6-800lbs worth of Engine/Transmission (and maybe driveshaft)… which has been replaced with 1,300lbs worth of batteries and 1,100lb worth of electrical motors, chargers, and inverters (in the case of the dual motor P100D). In fact, the drivetrain/battery in a Tesla is so heavy that Tesla had to resort to more exotic materials to lighten up the body, suspension, and interior. The battery, alone is about $12,000. Each powered axle subassembly is probably worth $2–4k each. There’s a lot of copper involved, too. Did I mention Teslas are super advanced? They have sensors all over them allowing them to be semi-autonomous and safe. If anything, Teslas are remarkably cheap, and they did so by making themselves into a luxury brand. It’s easier to absorb EV costs into a package that can be marketed alongside a BMW or Mercedes.

Essentially it’s the cost of the battery. Li-ion cells are a relatively new component (at least compared to something like a spark plug that has been around for 100 years) that until now has not been manufactured in quantities required for EVs. Therefore high volume manufacturing facilities and supply chains need to be set up to bring the cost down due to economies of scale. In addition, there is some technology learning at play here as well as a lot of research is being conducted to optimize the cell chemistry. All that is to say that at the moment, the battery is the main cost driver of EVs (including Teslas). However, the cost of Li-ion cells has been falling dramatically over the years, about 19% per year. That may not sound significant, but it adds up. In 2010 Li-ion cells cost $1000/kWh, meaning the 24 kWh battery in a Nissan LEAF of that time would have had $24,000 in Li-ion cells in it! Today, Tesla is at $100/kWh, meaning that the 75 kWh battery in the Tesla Model 3 Long Range (that can go about 4 times as far as that original Nissan LEAF) only has $7500 in cells! In another 4 years, we will start achieving cost parity with ICE cars, and it will only improve from there.

The cost of batteries, of course. But the simplicity of an electric motor and drive train compared to its ICE counterpart is monumental. Has anyone ever dissected an automatic transmission? The complexity is almost unbelievable. Ditto for the engine, now that they have introduced variable valve timing and a ton of other exotic improvements to the ancient design. An ICE drivetrain by now is so Rube Goldbergian that if the parts were spread out on the floor you would need a basketball court to contain them. And all of this just to squeeze another 1/2 mpg or a couple of horsepower or slightly lower emissions out of the old classic. In aviation we went from an 852-feet powered flight TO THE MOON in 66 years while pistons just keep chugging along as they did in Karl Benz’s day twice as long ago. I marvel that any manufacturer keeps spending money and increasingly complex engineering on a design that outlived its practical usefulness. At this point improvements to the ICE design are like doing a heart transplant on a terminal cancer patient. It’s an obsolete, dying technology. Why bother? Electrics are simpler, faster, and more economical to run. When the purchase price goes down — as it will, remember the Texas Instruments calculator? — ICE will be mercifully defunct. Oh, and why do I hate ICE so much? Because I have long done my own mechanical work on cars and motorcycles, and if I never rebuild another carburetor or replace a timing belt I will die a happy man with clean fingernails. (LOL)

Because Musk isn't good at running a business, especially a car one. He's made a lot of mistakes, that cost money and slowed down production. But the main thing is normal cars don't have a 28k battery!!! Even the gas motor in most cars don't cost that. But also, they haven't sold enough cars yet, why do you think the model T was so successful? Because they could crank them out, 45 minutes to assemble one, and they sold like crazy. Development costs were way cheaper back then. They haven't sold enough yet to recuperate the costs. And unlike Ford, who could sell just one model, they are trying to increase their sales with more models. Ford didn't even sell the cars in different colors!!!

Why are Tesla cars so expensive even though they have less parts than a normal car? The old dino burners are cheap as a result of about 100 years development - not so much of the CAR but of the manufacturing infrastructure EV’s are sufficiently different that a lot of that has needed to be re-developed So they “Cost” more now than they will in another few years The other reason is simpler Musk understood that the way you bring something NEW to market is you start at the top Start with expensive luxury models and work your way down the market - do you remember when Plasma TV’s were $10,000 ??

High-performance rechargeable lithium-ion battery cells. There are exactly 4416 #2170 lithium-ion battery cells in a Tesla Model 3 Long Range battery pack (96 series-connected “bricks” of 46 parallel-connected battery cells, arranged in four rows of 23/25/25/23). The Standard Range/Standard Range Plus battery packs have 2976 battery cells. Tesla Model 3: Exclusive first look at Tesla's new battery pack architecture - Electrek There are 8256 of the smaller #18650 lithium-ion battery cells in the battery pack of a Tesla Model S 100kW Long Range version, 7104 battery cells in the 85kW variants, and 5375 or 6216 battery cells in the 60kW variants. The Tesla Model X SUV is comparable (9/6/2019). As lithium-ion battery technology and manufacturing evolves and battery prices drop, BEV prices will become more competitive with obsolete ICE vehicles.

I do not consider them expensive. Comparing them with cars from the same segment (such as BMW, Audi, Mercedes) with the same performance, they are usually cheaper or are not so much expensive. You can compare a Model 3 with a BMW 3-series or a Audi A4 ou a Mercedes C-class and a Model S with a 5-series, an A6 our a E-Class. Do not forget to add all the possible comparable extras, such as electric seats, heated seats, automatic driving options etc, and choose an engine that gives the same performance as the Teslas. If you take in account the TCO (Total Cost of Ownership), with the savings in gas and maintenance, a Tesla is a lot cheaper.

The materials costs for a Model 3 are estimated to be around $18,000[1] (significantly lower than the Model S). That is not very different from the 50% materials costs for a conventional car. The rest of the price is assembly, distribution, R&D, marketing, Tesla’s debt, and so on. The largest single component is the battery price. Having fewer components is all well and good, unless one of those components is very expensive! Footnotes[1] Tesla Model 3 kann mit Gewinn gebaut werden

Quentin, I am not really poor nor rich, but I wish I could afford a TESLA X. [Although I am happy with my baby lincoln mkc]. I figure it is not just those electric motors & electronics [expensive at the start but we have now real production thus getting lower costs] it is the electronic storage ie batteries. To create these vehicles, that was of course a feat, but to create the storage capability for range is what boggles the minds of the inventors. And these “inventor-creators” guys are not coming cheap, trying to come up with workable solutions. They [TESLA] certainly have come far in range, from barely 200 miles range to a reasonable 400 mile. And what is really brilliant: bringing down the charge times from like weeeeeks into less than 1 hour for decent range. Now when you buy one new, you will have to pay for all that [and all their misses and near misses].

Part of the answer is that they use expensive battery technology developed primarily in house and these costs need to be paid by selling expensive cars. Partly it is due to having to finance their operations and build factories which Ford did 100 years ago (note: Tesla has raised a great deal of money through investors but those investors expect a return)Last the market is willing to pay that kind of money for being an early adopter and getting the prestige

If you count each battery cell as a part then Teslas have a lot of parts. And the battery is where most of the difference in cost is. Volume and automation will continue to bring the battery cost down. It is predicted that somewhere in the early 2020s and electric car will cost less to make and buy than an equivalent ICE vehicle. I eagerly await that day.

Think about your question. You are asking why a car which can out perform almost every other car on the road (in normal real life driving.) with fewer parts to fail, should cost more. Partially, BECAUSE it does what “normal cars” do in a much more advanced and efficient manner, with fewer things to go wrong.

That's a good question because Tesla doesn't have a dealer network to support either. Tesla spent a lot of money in developing a brand new vehicle and control systems in a short time. I hear that Tesla’s production process has a lot of labor involved as of yet and keeps cost higher. And, if you set a market price which people are willing to pay then why not charge it. The model 3 cost less than the model S so there's another way to go.

Since Evon Musk controls the show, someone has to pay the price. You're paying for a lot of research and development of this beautiful noiseless car. It has more power than all the other EVs. It goes farther on one charge and it's 0 to 60mph is the fastest so far than the other completion. I wouldn't buy an EV, but those that can afford it will. I'm presuming that those who have one can afford another SUV for the family if they have one.

Tesla does not have the vast economies of scale that major automakers enjoyTesla is a relatively less efficient carmaker than industry leaders such as ToyotaThe battery in an electric car is very expensive as compared to the power plant and transmission in an internal combustion engine car. This is largely offset over time by major savings in fuel and maintenance.

There's way more to a Tesla than the car. The software is ever improving even though they aren't getting anymore of my money. The structure Of the car is one of the safest out there. The charging infrastructure is the best in the world, and batteries. That is the single most expensive part of a Tesla. The good news is that materials for batteries are coming down in price.

Idiots buy them. Ask why diamonds are expensive. Also the batteries as mentioned before, half the price of Musk’s rust bucket is the Panasonic battery pack. without it it would’ve been a 50,000 dollar car with features and comfort of a 20,000 dollar one. Then again I am a biased BMW driver.

There are 3,000 lithium ion batteries in the Model 3. It takes a lot of time and money to manufacture, connect and mount all those batteries. Lithium ion batteries are not cheap. The Model S has 7,000 smaller batteries in it. The rest of the car is not that different than any other car.

First, they aren’t now. Go to Tesla’s website and the basic model 3 starts in the $30k range in the US. Second, it’s the first complete redesign of a car since the early 1900s. All others have taken what was done before and modified/improved it.

Because they’re brand new, unusual, exotic, and the people who buy one have just one-upped the entire neighborhood. I would guess that’s the guy with the biggest house, too. Probably the biggest ego, too. And Tesla is asking a lot of money, but they’re getting it. If people are paying, they’d be crazy to lower the price.

Because one part, the battery, is incredibly expensive, and more than compensates for the simplicity of the remainder of the car. Constructing thousands of tiny intricate cells is a very complex and time consuming task.

I think, the main reason is protectionism. Because of it China cannot sell its electric cars worldwide. If it could, the prices would be much lower. A secondary reason might be the necessity to maintain the fraction of electric cars rather small, because the electric grid is not adapted. Except in China, of course. The number of EV charging posts in China surpassed 1 million this year (it was one third of this last year), against 70,000 in the USA.

Ah yes, but each of the fewer parts cost more than the average part in a normal car. Also, you have to pay Elon’s developmental and marketing costs as well and maybe even cover part of the cost of Space X programme.
Q: Why are Tesla cars so expensive even though they have less parts than a normal car?A: Perhaps you have overlooked the “fact” there are over seven thousand “parts” in the Tesla battery alone?

Tesla is becoming obsolete. In case you haven’t been keeping up with the news they are facing bankruptcy and are moving production to China. Only the people who do not know and do not research don’t understand why teslas are so expensive. They are expensive because it is a fad
Lots of r&d. Components atr expensive. Plus I with s I understand profit per car was ~ 26% with proceeds poor into supercharger network, next model and gigafactory
There may not be a lot of different part types, there are a lot of those little battery cells, and in the quantity required, they cost a lot.
Because it Is the extreme in state of the art technology that is in a pioneer stage. Those that want aboard must pay dearly. Just American capitalism. God bless America!
